standard.description: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement. A square with side length 1 unit, called 'a unit square,' is said to have 'one square unit' of area, and can be used to measure area.

items: How to partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them

Area can be measured in square units

standard.description: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement. A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.

items: Area can be found by partitioning a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and counting the squares

standard.description: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Apply properties of operations to solve multi-step problems
Convert between different forms of rational numbers as needed

standard.description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

items: Basic probability concepts
How to develop probability models
The difference between theoretical and experimental probability
Methods for collecting and organizing data
Probability models can predict likely outcomes
Why theoretical and experimental probabilities might differ
How to evaluate the effectiveness of a probability model
The relationship between relative frequency and probability
Develop and use probability models
Calculate theoretical probabilities
Compare predicted and observed frequencies
Explain discrepancies between models and observations

standard.description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

items: What compound events are
Different ways to organize probability outcomes
How to use tree diagrams and tables
Basic concepts of simulation
How to identify all possible outcomes of compound events
Why different organizational methods work
The relationship between theoretical and simulated probability
When to use different probability tools
Create organized lists and tables for compound events
Construct and use tree diagrams
Design and conduct probability simulations
Calculate probabilities using various methods

standard.description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.

items: How to write numbers in scientific notation
Powers of 10 and their properties
Place value concepts with very large and very small numbers
How to compare numbers using scientific notation
Scientific notation is useful for expressing very large or very small quantities
How to interpret numbers written in scientific notation
The relationship between the power of 10 and the size of the number
How to compare magnitudes of numbers in scientific notation
Express numbers in scientific notation
Compare quantities written in scientific notation
Estimate large and small quantities using powers of 10
Determine relative sizes of quantities in scientific notation

standard.description: Solve linear equations in one variable. a. Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers). b. Solve linear equations and inequalities with rational number coefficients, including those whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

items: Properties of equality and operations
The concept of equivalent equations
Different types of solution possibilities for linear equations
The distributive property and how to collect like terms
How to work with rational number coefficients
The meaning of variables and coefficients
Why some equations have one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions
How transforming equations leads to equivalent forms
The relationship between equation forms and their solutions
When and how to apply the distributive property
How to determine the number of solutions an equation has
Solve linear equations with rational coefficients
Transform equations to determine solution types
Apply the distributive property to expand expressions
Combine like terms to simplify expressions
Identify equations with one, none, or infinitely many solutions
Verify solutions through substitution

standard.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations. a. Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously. b. Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection. c. Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.

items: What a system of linear equations represents
Methods for solving systems of equations
The relationship between graphs and solutions
How to interpret points of intersection
Different solution possibilities for systems
Real-world applications of systems
Solutions to systems are points that satisfy both equations
The connection between algebraic and graphical solutions
Why some systems have one, no, or infinitely many solutions
How to choose appropriate solution methods
When to use systems to model real situations
Graph pairs of linear equations
Find intersection points of linear equations
Solve systems using algebraic methods
Estimate solutions using graphs
Apply systems to solve real-world problems
Verify solutions satisfy both equations

standard.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations: a. Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length. b. Angles are taken to angles of the same measure. c. Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.

items: Properties of rotations, reflections, and translations
Characteristics of lines, line segments, and angles
The concept of parallel lines
How transformations affect geometric figures
Methods for measuring angles and lengths
Transformations preserve the properties of geometric figures
How each type of transformation affects a figure
Why parallel lines remain parallel under transformations
The relationship between original and transformed figures
How to verify transformation properties experimentally
Perform rotations, reflections, and translations
Verify that transformations preserve length and angle measures
Demonstrate that parallel lines remain parallel
Use appropriate tools to measure and compare figures
Explain how transformations affect geometric properties

standard.description: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.

items: How to multiply and divide within 100
How to represent word problems using equations
The difference between multiplicative and additive comparison
How to use symbols to represent unknown quantities
Basic multiplication and division facts
Multiplicative comparison involves comparing quantities using multiplication or division
The difference between multiplicative and additive comparison situations
How to interpret word problems to determine appropriate operations
The relationship between multiplication and division in word problems
How to use drawings and equations to represent problem situations
Solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison
Use drawings to represent multiplicative situations
Write equations with variables for unknown values
Distinguish between multiplicative and additive comparison situations
Apply appropriate operations to solve comparison problems

standard.description: Interpret multiplication as scaling (resizing), by: a. Comparing the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor, without performing the indicated multiplication. b. Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (n × a)/(n × b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.

items: The Identity Property of Multiplication
How to compare fractions to benchmarks 0, ½, and 1
Multiplication is used for resizing (scaling)
Multiplication can produce an answer less than one or both factors
Properties of multiplication with whole numbers
The concept of fraction equivalence
Multiplying by a fraction less than 1 will yield a product less than one of the factors
When multiplying by ½, the product is half the value of that factor
The relationship between fraction multiplication and scaling
Why multiplying by a fraction greater than 1 increases the product
Why multiplying by a fraction less than 1 decreases the product
How fraction equivalence relates to multiplying by 1
Compare products to factors without performing multiplication
Predict the relative size of products based on the factors
Explain the effect of multiplying by fractions greater than or less than 1
Use patterns to reason about multiplication with fractions
Apply the principle of fraction equivalence
Justify predictions about product size using mathematical reasoning

standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions. a. Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for (1/3) ÷ 4, and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that (1/3) ÷ 4 = 1/12 because (1/12) × 4 = 1/3. b. Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for 4 ÷ (1/5), and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that 4 ÷ (1/5) = 20 because 20 × (1/5) = 4. c. Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: How to divide whole numbers and what it means to divide using the partitioning and repeated subtraction models
Division is the inverse of multiplication
How to use visual models to divide whole numbers with and without remainders
How to contextualize division problems using whole numbers
Division is not a commutative operation
Unit fractions have a numerator of one and can be combined to create non-unit fractions

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: Creating a visual model to represent problems helps give meaning to the problem and what is happening in the problem
The division model used to solve a problem depends on the context of the problem
The role of the dividend, divisor, and quotient
A fraction can be divided by a whole number and the result will be less than the original fraction because it was partitioned into pieces
A whole number can be divided by a fraction and the result will be greater than the original whole number
Various models can be used to illustrate given problems

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Create visual models and divide unit fractions by whole numbers
Reason through division problems involving fractions and whole numbers
Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number and compute quotients
Create visual models to divide a whole number by a unit fraction
Create and solve word problems involving division of unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions
Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain solutions

standard.description: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers. a. Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram. For example, interpret –3 > –7 as a statement that –3 is located to the right of –7 on a number line oriented from left to right. b. Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts. For example, write –3°C > -7°C to express the fact that –3°C is warmer than -7°C. c. Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation. For example, for an account balance of –30 dollars, write |–30| = 30 to describe the size of the debt in dollars. d. Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order. For example, recognize that an account balance less than –30 dollars represents a debt greater than 30 dollars.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: Numbers to the right of zero are positive on a number line diagram
Numbers to the left of zero are negative on a number line diagram
Relation symbols are <, >, ≤, ≥, and ≠
Rational numbers may include whole numbers, integers, fractions, and decimals
Absolute value is the distance a number is from 0 on the number line
The symbol for absolute value is | |

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: The further left a number is from zero, the more negative (smaller) it is
The further right a number is from zero, the more positive (larger) it is
When comparing any two numbers on a number line diagram, the number to the left is always smaller if the number line is oriented from left to right
Since absolute value refers to distance from zero, it is always represented by a positive number
Using a number line diagram as a tool for comparison
Absolute value may not be limited to integers

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Describe the relative position of two numbers on a number line when given an inequality
Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram
Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts
Order rational numbers least to greatest or greatest to least
Find the absolute value of a rational number
Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order

standard.description: Apply and extend previous understanding of addition and subtraction to add and subtract integers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram. a. Understand that the absolute value of a number is its distance from zero and that since absolute value is a measure of distance, it always has a positive value. b. Understand p + q as the number located a distance |q| from p, in the positive or negative direction depending on whether q is positive or negative. Show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Interpret sums of integers by describing real-world contexts. c. Understand subtraction of integers as adding the additive inverse, p – q = p + (-q). Show that the distance between two integers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference, and apply this principle in real-world contexts. d. Apply properties of operations to add and subtract integers.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero
Since absolute value is a measure of distance, it always has a positive value
The difference between the absolute value of a number and its opposite
Opposites are additive inverses
The associative property of addition: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
The commutative property of addition: a + b = b + a
The additive identity property of zero: a + 0 = 0 + a = a
The distributive property of multiplication over addition and subtraction

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: How to find absolute value of a number vs. finding its opposite
A positive integer added to a positive integer results in a positive integer
A negative integer added to a negative integer results in a negative integer
Applying appropriate properties to add or subtract integers
The relationship between addition and subtraction with integers
How to use a number line to represent addition and subtraction of integers

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Use a horizontal or vertical number line to add p + q, regardless of whether either number is positive or negative
Use a horizontal or vertical number line to show that a number and its opposite have a sum of zero
Interpret sums of integers in real-world contexts
Add or subtract integers with or without a number line
Add or subtract integers with or without a four-function calculator
Demonstrate understanding of adding and subtracting by recognizing equivalent expressions

standard.description: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b≠0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship. For example, 'This recipe has a ratio of 3 cups of flour to 4 cups of sugar, so there is 3/4 cup of flour for each cup of sugar.' 'We paid $75 for 15 hamburgers, which is a rate of $5 per hamburger.'

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: A rate indicates, for a proportional relationship between two quantities, how many units of one quantity there are for every one unit of the second quantity
A unit rate is a ratio, a:b, where b = 1
The unit price is the cost per unit
Dividing the numerator by the denominator will find the unit rate

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: Equivalent fractions as equivalent ratios
Interpreting a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator
Descriptions of a unit rate include words such as per, in, and for every

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Convert a given ratio to a unit rate
Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems
Compare unit rates
Calculate and justify the best buy using unit price
Use a four-function calculator for computations

standard.description: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by: a. Reporting the number of observations. b. Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement. c. Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered. d. Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: The definition and purpose of measures of center (mean, median, mode)
The definition and purpose of measures of variability (range, interquartile range, mean absolute deviation)
How to calculate various statistical measures
The importance of units of measurement in data collection
How data distribution shapes can be described

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: The relationship between data distribution shape and appropriate measures of center
How context influences the choice of statistical measures
The significance of sample size in data analysis
How to identify and interpret patterns and deviations in data
The importance of considering both center and spread in data analysis

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Calculate and interpret measures of center and variability
Report the number of observations in a dataset
Describe attributes and their units of measurement
Analyze patterns and deviations in data distributions
Select appropriate statistical measures based on data context and distribution

items: Add rational numbers in real-world contexts

standard.description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities. a. Decide whether two quantities are in a proportional relationship, e.g., by testing for equivalent ratios in a table or graphing on a coordinate plane and observing whether the graph is a straight line through the origin. b. Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships. c. Represent proportional relationships by equations. d. Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation, with special attention to the points (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: How to make and reason about tables of equivalent ratios
How to plot points in the coordinate plane
How to identify and use unit rates
How to write and solve equations
The meaning of proportional relationships
How to model relationships using various representations

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: The characteristics of proportional relationships in tables, graphs, and equations
The significance of (0,0) and (1,r) in graphs of proportional relationships
How to identify and interpret the constant of proportionality
The connections between different representations of proportional relationships
How context influences the interpretation of points on a graph

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: Determine if two quantities are proportional using tables, graphs, or equations
Find and interpret the constant of proportionality in various representations
Write equations to represent proportional relationships
Explain the meaning of points on graphs in context
Convert between different representations of proportional relationships
Solve real-world problems involving proportional relationships
